title: What is the most frequently conquered and occupied piece of land in history? - Quora

response.answer_text: My candidate would be Israel/Palestine.  From earliest times, it was a buffer region between Egypt, which was the richest prize from ancient history until not that long ago, and any invader coming in from the Asian landmass.  And in the other direction, it was also the route through which Egyptian armies had to go whenever they were strong enough to expand Egyptian power.   Can't think of any century in recorded history when some hostile army wasn't tramping up or down that region. On top of the dizzying array of wars recorded during Pharaonic Egypt and the Old Testament, here are just some of the invasions that went through there off the top of my head: 500s BC, Persians gobbling it up en route to Egypt400s BC, Persians putting down rebellions in Egypt and Egyptians rebelling and setting out from Egypt to points north300s BC, Alexander the Great200s BC, various wars between Hellenic kingdoms in Egypt and Syria100s BC, see preceding1st C. BC, see preceding + Romans1st C. AD, Romans putting down rebellions2nd C. AD, Romans putting down rebellions3rd C. AD, Parthians, Romans, Palmyrians4th C. AD, Parthians, Sassanids, Byzantines5th C. AD, Sassanids6th C. AD, Sassanids7th C. AD, Sassanids + Arabs8th C. AD, Byzantines9th C. AD, Byzantines + various fragmented Arab statelets10th C. AD, Fatimids vs Abasids11th C. AD, Fatimids vs Abasids + Crusaders12th C. AD, Crusaders + Islamic reconquest13th C. AD, Crusaders + Islamic reconquest + Mongols + Mamelukes14th C. AD, Mamelukes vs various Turks15th C. AD, Mamelukes vs various Turks16th C. AD, Ottoman Turks17th C. AD, rebellions in Egypt, Ottoman response18th C. AD, rebellions in Egypt, Ottoman response, + French19th C. AD, Khedieval Egypt20th C. AD, British + various Arab-Israeli wars

Damascus, in what’s now Syria. It’s the longest continually-inhabited city in the world. There has been a city on that spot for at least 11,000 years, and it must surely have been occupied and re-occupied hundreds of times in 110 centuries of being home to human beings. Bakery in Damascus today . . .  Ancient Syrian quern stone for grinding flour, c. 9000 BC. . .
